metadata.title: Modelling hate speech in Polish: Importance of domain-specific embeddings | by Mikołaj Małkiński | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Modelling hate speech in Polish: Importance of domain-specific embeddings
metadata.description: At Sotrender we enhance digital marketing with AI by applying in-house built machine learning models to social media. Our latest challenge was hate speech detection in Polish messages. Below you can…

A Simple Neural Network for Cyberbullying Detection

all_paragraphs: At Sotrender we enhance digital marketing with AI by applying in-house built machine learning models to social media. Our latest challenge was hate speech detection in Polish messages. Below you can find how we approached the problem and the results we obtained.

In the era of the Internet, discussions are being held online on various communication platforms instead of face-to-face. The lack of direct recipients of our messages can give a deceptive sense of anonymity. This allows us to express ourselves more freely, but on the other hand, ignore the fact that our texts will be read by another person. This is also known as the online disinhibition effect. Additionally, people aren’t forced to take responsibility for the words they post online most of the time. These points result in a noticeable hatred found inside online discussions.

Thanks to the recent advances in Natural Language Processing (NLP), more and more harmful messages can be detected automatically. However, the mainstream of NLP research focuses only on a small subset of either commonly-spoken languages or those with a big population, such as English or Chinese (see [1] for a comprehensive study of linguistic diversity in NLP). This creates a noticeable discrepancy between the quality of NLP models (and hence the ability to detect harmful content) depending on the language they’re directed towards. Although some recent studies aim to bridge this gap by developing multilingual models, most of the time those directed towards a single language present better language understanding capabilities. Fortunately, some new possibilities are emerging in order to support the research for under-represented languages.

In this article, we’ll be focusing on the problem of hate speech detection in the Polish language. We’ll start by describing a recently created dataset which can be used as a benchmark for hate speech detection methods. Then, we’ll discuss our approach which is based on a fast and simple deep learning model. We compared our method with submissions from the PolEval competition and from the KLEJ benchmark. The proposed model achieves significant improvement over results from PolEval and is on par with Transformer-based models from KLEJ, while being much simpler conceptually and requiring less computational resources. The strength of our method showcases the importance of domain-specific text embeddings and usage of a neural module well-suited for the task at hand.

PolEval is an evaluation campaign for NLP tools crafted specifically for the Polish language. Starting from 2017, they hold yearly competitions with various language understanding tasks such as Machine Translation or Named Entity Recognition. In 2019, one of the tasks tackled the problem of detecting harmful content amongst messages gathered from discussions held on public forums. Namely, the task “Automatic cyberbullying detection”, which is divided into 2 parts, aims to differentiate between non-harmful and harmful messages or to further classify the harmful ones as either cyberbullying or hate speech. Although at first glance the distinction between cyberbullying and hate speech may not be clear, the task differentiates them based on the target of a given harmful action: in cyberbullying it’s addressed towards an individual, whereas in hate speech towards a group or an entity. More detailed definitions are addressed in a paper which accompanies the task [2].

The dataset used for this task is composed of tweets gathered from publicly available Twitter discussions. The tweets are minimally preprocessed so that they don’t contain identifying information about private individuals. Besides that, their original format is unchanged. That means, they can contain emojis, smileys, hashtags, HTTP URLs and noise such as typos. Although URLs generally don’t contain useful information regarding the harmfulness of a message, emojis, smileys and hashtags can be used to either strengthen the content of the text or indicate sarcasm. An example from the dataset is shown below:

An additional challenge in detecting harmful messages comes from the topic of discussion. A large number of messages from the dataset are connected to politics. In general, one can suspect that messages posted on online platforms regarding politics may contain more negative sentiment. A model trained on such data may learn undesirable bias and consider all messages regarding this topic as more likely to be harmful. In general, the tweets from the dataset refer to politics, sports and news (more detailed description can be found in [2]).

Lastly, the dataset may be considered as challenging from the point of view of machine learning (ML) models. It contains around 11k tweets (10k devoted for the training set and 1k for testing) which is a rather small number when compared to other NLP tasks. Additionally, the class distribution is severely imbalanced as the majority of texts are non-harmful (see Figure 1).

Most state-of-the-art NLP models are pre-trained on well-structured documents, such as articles from Wikipedia, which allows us to build a rich and accurate language model. However, these pre-trained models may not necessarily know how to deal with special tokens such as new emojis, hashtags or completely new phrases specific to social media communication, which they weren’t trained on. The existence of different language styles, abbreviations, slang, mixing words from different languages or simply typos or grammatical errors will further test models’ ability to generalise out-of-distribution data. However, token embedding methods which handle out-of-vocabulary keys may partially solve this problem.

Additionally, the majority of these models use the Transformer [3] architecture. Although recently it has been a standard choice for most NLP problems, it requires extensive computational resources when compared to simpler methods such as FastText [4,5]. This property has to be taken into consideration when developing a model for production environments. The inference time of Transformer-based models, even when deployed on instances with access to GPUs, may result in latency that is too high. Moreover, deployment of multiple replicas with GPUs may be impossible, simply due to high financial costs.

Keeping both of these aspects in mind, we base our approach on a low-latency token embedding model, trained specifically on data coming from social media and combine it with a simple and efficient classification head. Given a message, we start with simple preprocessing steps:
The result is a cleaned message, which is then split into tokens which can be encoded as vectors using a token embedding model.

Instead of using an already pre-trained token embedding model, we decided to train a new one from scratch, exclusively on our own social media dataset. Majority of the dataset comes from Facebook posts and comments gathered across a time span of several years. Additionally, it contains texts from other social media platforms, such as Instagram or YouTube. We selected only Polish texts using another model for language detection. In total, the dataset consisted of 1 billion words, with more than 3 million unique ones. The texts were subject to minimal preprocessing, which mainly removed the urls, encoded all emojis and smileys to special tokens and included them in our vocabulary. However, we didn’t correct any typos.

Although recent works mainly focus on Transformer-based architectures, we’ve chosen FastText as the token embedding model, because of several reasons. Firstly, quick inference time and low computational requirements make the model easy to deploy. Secondly, FastText uses character-level information which makes the method well-suited for morphologically-rich languages, such as Polish.

It’s worth pointing out that creating the model from scratch required a significant amount of time, not only for training, which we completed within a day, but also for the preparation of the dataset. Nonetheless, in Sotrender we work with data coming mainly from social media, so we are able to use this model in other NLP tasks, such as Sentiment Analysis. Moreover, training a Transformer-based model, such as BERT, is usually not your first choice as it has high hardware requirements, takes even more time than FastText and therefore is simply expensive. We think that in practice it’s better to start with a simpler solution and gradually increase the complexity, only when it’s necessary.

At this point, it’s important to observe that in many cases the task of detecting hate speech can be tackled by searching for a harmful sequence of words (tokens) inside a sentence. Oftentimes it’s enough to identify such a sequence, without the need to analyse the context of a whole message. Motivated by this observation, we employed a 1-dimensional Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) directly after the token embedding model. The translation invariance, which is incorporated inside CNN architecture, allows us to exactly process such sequences of tokens. Moreover, by considering all such subarrays of list of tokens with fixed-width (size of convolutions’ kernel), we are able to create a representation of the whole sentence. A similar approach can be found in some other works [6, 7], or even in the Bag-of-Words (BoW) model, which considers n-grams of tokens. Figure 2 demonstrates how 1D convolution can be applied to a sequence of token embeddings.

Although CNNs are mostly known from Computer Vision problems, our approach demonstrates that they work just as well for sequence processing tasks including text classification, while being less computationally demanding than recurrent modules. We also tried replacing CNN with other architectures prominent in sequence processing, including Long Short Term Memory (LSTM) or Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU), but the best results were achieved using single-layer CNN with a pooling layer.

To sum up, token embeddings are transformed using a shallow 1-dimensional CNN with a pooling layer and projected into class distribution using a learned linear transformation followed by a softmax. Additionally, we use l2-regularization and dropout on the penultimate layer. The complete architecture is presented in Figure 3.

During training, the weights of the token embedding model are frozen and the remaining learnable parameters of the network are optimized. In most experiments we use a validation dataset (extracted using stratified sampling from training split) for early-stopping and selecting hyperparameters, unless otherwise noted. Additionally, we apply simple data augmentation during training, which shuffles and removes randomly chosen tokens. We plan to conduct a comprehensive review of tested augmentation methods in a future article.

We conducted the evaluation of our approach in two steps. Firstly, we compared it with the best models submitted for PolEval2019 Task 6. The comparison includes both binary (task 6.1) and multi-class (task 6.2) versions of this task. Next, we looked at the results of large transformer models evaluated using the CBD task from the KLEJ benchmark [8]. Due to the imbalanced class distributions, models were compared using F1-score for the binary classification task and both Micro-F1 and Macro-F1 in case of multi-class classification.

We compared our model with five of the best competitors in both tasks. Interestingly, the submissions contain a number of different approaches. For task 6.1, the best results (Table 1) were achieved by the following methods:
Best performing methods in task 6.2 (Table 2), additionally include:

As seen in both tables, our approach exceeds other reported results by a significant margin. It’s important to recall that our model isn’t based on complex features, such as [10] or [14], nor relies on big architectures as [9] and [11]. The visible improvement comes from using domain specific embeddings, which were trained on data similar to modeled task/problem.

To further demonstrate the strength of our model, we compared it with transformer-based methods evaluated in the KLEJ benchmark [8]. Amongst many tasks, it includes cyberbullying detection (CBD), which uses the same dataset as in task 6.1 of PolEval2019. For the purpose of fair comparison, we follow the setup from [15] and train the model on the whole training split.

As can be seen from the table, although we don’t reach the top of the leaderboard, we achieve comparable results. Our model is placed on the 4th position, surpassing the performance of other models based on BERT, RoBERTa or XLM.

In this article, we’ve shown that implementing complex architectures or increasing the number of models’ parameters isn’t the only path to success. Our approach argues that another key ingredient is to use domain-specific inductive biases. In our case, these biases exist mainly in the token embedding module, but also in CNN which is well-suited for the problem of hate speech detection.

Because of the simplicity of our approach, we were able to successfully deploy our model into a production environment. The inference process can be carried out without a GPU and requires only a single CPU with less than 3GB of RAM. This results in a low-cost solution which is easy to scale horizontally. If you are interested in how we deployed our model, then put the questions in the comments and we will try to prepare an article about it as well.
The key observation to take from this article, is to realize that even in the world of Transformers, hammers can be replaced by screwdrivers.
[2] M. E. Ptaszynski and F. Masui eds., Automatic Cyberbullying Detection: Emerging Research and Opportunities: Emerging Research and Opportunities (2018), IGI Global 2018
[3] A. Vaswani et al., Attention is all you need (2017), Advances in neural information processing systems 2017
[6] B. Gambäck and U. K. Sikdar, Using convolutional neural networks to classify hate-speech (2017), Proceedings of the first workshop on abusive language online
[7] S. Bai, J. Z. Kolter and V. Koltun, An empirical evaluation of generic convolutional and recurrent networks for sequence modeling (2018), arXiv preprint arXiv:1803.01271
[9] P. Czapla et al., Universal language model fine-tuning for polish hate speech detection (2019), Proceedings of the PolEval 2019 Workshop: 149
[11] R. Korzeniowski et al., Exploiting Unsupervised Pre-training and Automated Feature Engineering for Low-resource Hate Speech Detection in Polish (2019), arXiv preprint arXiv:1906.09325

[12] M. Biesek, Comparison of Traditional Machine Learning Approach and Deep Learning Models in Automatic Cyberbullying Detection for Polish Language (2019), Proceedings of the PolEval 2019 Workshop: 121
[13] K. Wróbel, Approaching automatic cyberbullying detection for Polish tweets (2019)
[14] K. Krasnowska-Kieras and A. Wróblewska, A Simple Neural Network for Cyberbullying Detection (2019), Proceedings of the PolEval 2019 Workshop: 161
Machine Learning Engineer at Sotrender. Daily applies AI and ML to social media.
